Title:
PHYLOGENETIC SPECIES RECOGNITION CRITERIA ACROSS A SIX COUNTY
SURVEY OF INDIANAS MORPHOLOGICALLY DIVERSE YELLOW MORELS (MORCHELLA
ESCULENTA GROUP) REVEALS THE MAJORITY COMPRISE A SINGLE SPECIES, M.
AMERICANA
Abstract:
Characterizing morel (Morchella spp.) diversity is
challenging due to the limitations in both morphological species
recognition (MSR) and the single locus internal transcribed spacer (ITS)
barcoding criteria. In many regions, the phenotypic diversity within and
between species makes it difficult to accurately characterize species
diversity with morphological data, and the ITS locus alone
underestimates Morchella species diversity. Due to inconsistencies with
these methods, the current standard for assessing morel diversity is
through the phylogenetic species recognition (PSR) criteria using a
multilocus molecular data set. A series of multilocus phylogenetic
analyses worldwide have identified at least 65 phylogenetically distinct
morel species, yet Morchella diversity in many locations has not been
assessed. To begin evaluating the morel diversity in Indiana, we
collected morels from six counties every spring in 2013, 2014, and 2015.
Species diversity was measured through both single, and multilocus
phylogenetic species recognition (PSR) criteria of three loci,
previously used to resolve Morchella diversity: elongation factor
1-alpha (EF1-α), the second largest RNA polymerase subunit (RPB2), and
nuclear ribosomal large subunit (LSU) 28S rDNA. Despite tremendous
variability in sporocarp morphology, over 94% of 132 morels analyzed
were resolved to one phylogenetic species, M. americana. The application
of PSR criteria with EF1-α expedited the characterization of species
diversity in later years of our collections. EF1-α was also the only
locus that provided significant bootstrap support and topology
resolution in phylogenetic constructions. Our results describe the
sporocarp variability among M. americana in a region where morel
diversity has not been assessed, as well as methodologies to expedite
this process in other locations.
